metadata.title: Bright Orange Nurse Shark Spotted Off Costa Rica in Possible First Caribbean Case of Xanthism

left: A bright orange shark with striking white eyes was discovered in the Caribbean, exhibiting traits of albinism and xanthism.
Researchers from the Federal University of Rio Grande stated that the phenomenon of xanthism in cartilaginous fish has never been documented in the Caribbean before.
The unusual shark's survival into adulthood raises significant questions about shark genetics and adaptability.
This discovery highlights the unique combination of xanthism and albinism in the yellowfin shark.
center: A bright orange shark with striking white eyes was discovered in the Caribbean, exhibiting traits of albinism and xanthism.
Researchers from the Federal University of Rio Grande stated that the phenomenon of xanthism in cartilaginous fish has never been documented in the Caribbean before.
The unusual shark's survival into adulthood raises significant questions about shark genetics and adaptability.
This discovery highlights the unique combination of xanthism and albinism in the yellowfin shark.
right: A fisherman on the coast of Costa Rica caught a bright orange shark with white eyes, marking an extremely rare find.
The shark measures over six feet long and has a condition linked to xanthism, causing its unusual bright orange body.
The shark also shows signs of albinism, particularly in its white eyes, making its discovery remarkable.
This discovery is significant for science, necessitating two pigment pathways to be interrupted simultaneously.
